channel.name: Create smartcontract in an other language ?

messages.content:
Hello, actually we can use js/ts to create smartcontract with o1js, but can we use an other language to do the same thing ?
If we can use an other language what is the performande difference to create a proof ?

I'm interested to build a system to delegate proof creation to a server.
If I'm not mistaken the proof creation part is implemented in OCaml and o1js uses its bindings.

Why do you need another language for a server? The performance depends upon o1js prover code that is OCaml and will be affected in the server environment by CPU and memory available, not by the SmartContract language

If you do recursive proofs, you can calculate them in parallel, gaining logarithmic savings in time

https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js-bindings/

embeds.title: GitHub - o1-labs/o1js-bindings: Bindings for o1js to lower layers o...
embeds.description: Bindings for o1js to lower layers of the proof system and the Mina transaction logic - GitHub - o1-labs/o1js-bindings: Bindings for o1js to lower layers of the proof system and the Mina transaction...

messages.content: you can do it in ocaml and it's ~10 times faster

Because when you launch it on browser it can take some seconds or minutes to make a proof, you can’t get engagement with this type of solution.

So it’s possible to « compile » it on node to use ocaml/rust when is executed, js is not a performant language it’s why I ask that
Oh nice do you have some example ?
https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/tree/develop/src/app/zkapps_examples

embeds.title: mina/src/app/zkapps_examples at develop · MinaProtocol/mina
embeds.description: Mina is a cryptocurrency protocol with a constant size blockchain, improving scaling while maintaining decentralization and security. - MinaProtocol/mina

messages.content: Thanks I will check
oh is this really true? I wonder how that happens. Does the extra overhead come because of the js bindings?

There aren't bindings to ocaml, it's ocaml compiled to js. WASM is compiled kimchi backend which is in rust. So the whole ocaml part is slow because it runs in js. But yeah still it doesn't sound like it should be that much slower, but I haven't investigated.
oh ok i see, so what you were saying was that if we didn't have the whole "ocaml -> js compile" thing, it would probably be much faster?
I hope I'm understanding that correctly 😅
See also Gregor’s note on exposing rust binary: https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1156895869036142663/1159070288953221130

Can you please explain it in more detail?

We have two long processes: SmartContract.compile() and tx.prove()
As I understand, tx.prove() runs inside WASM32 code that is compiled from rust and uses prover keys from SmartContract.compile()

What about SmartContract.compile()? Is it JS code compiled from OCaml?

> but can we use an other language to do the same thing ?

The short answer is YES. You can use any language. In fact, I have attempted to implement some parts in Python (creation of Mina-compatible signatures).

The problem is that you will need to redo all of the abstraction work that O1JS did for you. 

I'm highly incentivising you to try O1JS and TypeScript. zkLocus (https://zklocus.dev) is my first project implemented in both TypeScript and O1JS. I've looked into other Zero-Knowledge application solutions, but O1JS is a clear winner in clarity, conciseness and elegancy.

The community is also here to help you learn. A lot!

embeds.title: zkLocus | Home
embeds.description: Authenticated private geolocation for blockchain, mobile, and web, on or off-chain.

messages.content:
I know I can recreate the full process in an other language, but I would to know if they already exist in an other language to maybe use it.

I already use o1js for my game but I can use proof for ingame action, it's too slow and users will stop playing it, if I want to implement proof for in game action I need a solution to create proof in less than 3sec
Maybe I will try to recreate O1js in c#, I already reimplement one part of mina signer in c#, but all O1js is huge, all provable mechanisms
@Youtpout look into FFI (Foreign Function Interface). This way, you can execute O1JS's TypeScript code in C#. But since O1JS is being actively upgraded, you'll end up having a lot of mainatance.
I try to improve proof execution, not to lower him
I will try to compare excution on node than browser in first place

Kimchi is implemented in rust and Pickles (recursive layer) is implemented in ocaml. O1js needs both, so kimchi is compiled to wasm, pickles is compiled to js and then there is a thin layer connecting them + some ts code for nicer interface.

I've tried to reimplement the basic recursive circuit from tutorial (https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/recursion) in ocaml and measure both.

```
|        |  Ocaml  |  o1js  |
-----------------------------
|  comp  |  ~8s    |  ~44s  |
|  base  |  ~2.3s  |  ~18s  |
|  step  |  ~4s    |  ~39s  |
```

I've tested it on apple silicon cpu, which has poor multi threaded performance in wasm (https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js-bindings/blob/main/js/node/node-backend.js#L138-L146), but still you will probably run into users using macbooks.

So if you want to have 3 seconds proofs, your best bet is to use ocaml on server.

Thank you for the explanations and test results; very helpful.

Does any way exist to embed OCaml code inside TypeScript and run it, similar to `assembly { ... }` in solidity?

Can you share your OCaml example code to see how it looks like?
Good job, it’s concluant results, share you example please, I will try on ryzen 7950
even after adjusting for better wasm thread usage the wasm prover is about 3x slower
i have also traced the calls to the wasm prover from the compiled snarkyml, and there are maybe 4-5 calls that could be replaced with calls to the native prover instead of the wasm prover
https://github.com/MartinOndejka/snarkyml_vs_o1js/ here I've pushed the repo
That wouldn't help you much since you would still have slow prover. What you want is to run proving and compiling in native binary.
Definition of circuits can theoretically still be in ts.

this is achievable by building in the native prover binary support to o1js, and delegating the in-js-snarkyml calls to kimchi from the kimchi wasm to kimchi native, there’s about 4-5 calls to the wasm code that need to be substituted with e.g. IPC calls to native kimchi. this will bring the server side proving performance to native levels
Looks like great project for cohort 3

its something we’re considering working on for Protokit, wasm proving still works, but its about 3-4x slower on comparable hardware resources. This results into either slower UX on proven L1 settlements or higher hardware costs - so instead of 0.01$ per tx you’ll end up with 0.03$ per tx to offset the hardware requirements

i’ve managed to get better wasm performance on my M1 max as well like this: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js-bindings/issues/223

the same needs to be done for all other mac cpus

embeds.title: Adjust efficient num workers for Apple M1 Max · Issue #223 · o1-lab...
embeds.description: I was investigating proving performance on Apple M1 Max, and managed to double the proving speed by adjusting the number of threads/workers used in this config: o1js-bindings/js/node/node-backend.j...

messages.content: I have M2 Max, can do for it if you will explain how to test

clone o1js repo, then init git submodules to pull in the bindings repo. then go here and edit to match your real thread count: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js-bindings/blob/c5aa5f163bf9e86adea3b85cdb75d84e56b9d461/js/node/node-backend.js#L142

Make sure to run a new nodejs version like i described in my issue.

then write a sample circuit in examples/, and run it with accordance to the ‘dev readme’ in o1js repo - you’ll have to remove one argument from the run.sh something like experimental wasm threads - bcs thats no longer required in newest node

embeds.title: o1js-bindings/js/node/node-backend.js at c5aa5f163bf9e86adea3b85cdb...
embeds.description: Bindings for o1js to lower layers of the proof system and the Mina transaction logic - o1-labs/o1js-bindings

messages.content:
Best to write a zk program with 0-2^16 variable constraints, meaning you e.g. do a for loop of a variable size so you can test diff circuit sizes.

i think my m1 max config was something like ‘9’ threads in this config above ^^ and i got like 7-14s in proving performance for 0-2^16 circuit size
in theory maybe you can remove the custom settings for mac cpus, but m1 max has 10 cores / 10 threads, no multi threading. And 8 perf cores with 3ghz and 2 economical cores with like 2.3ghz or so.
the step method here takes 24s running on 8 threads on my m1 max
thats 6x slower wasm proving than native
We will run some more benchmarks and then likely remove the thread limit for M1s and M2s after confirming that its no longer a problem for most chips

Lovely thread! I'm also running performance investigations of o1js from time to time, this is a breakdown of where the effort in a proof for Keccak + ECDSA (2^16 size) is spent:

```
prove 39 sec 

%
57.7 wasm: create step proof (22.6s)
19.3 wasm: create wrap proof (7.6s)
 9.2 decodeProverKey w/ serde (3.6s)
 5.1 ts field inverse (2s)
 2.5 fieldTo/FromRust (1s)

= 93.8% explained
```

As this shows, almost 90%  is spent in the Wasm compiled from Kimchi (and the remaining 10% include things that I know how to make much faster in JS or have already done so)

So, the main thing to do is to replace the Wasm calls, just as @maht0rz suggested.

That's why my vision for a native backend would actually not involve swapping the OCaml -> JS code with a native binary, but only swapping the Rust -> Wasm -- OCaml can just stay compiled to JS  (the API surface from Rust is much smaller, so this is easier to do, and it's nice if the whole circuit writing apparatus can stay as is)
the pickles stuff remains in js_of_ocaml right?

What I also want to work on in the very near future is faster Wasm arithmetic. I think the Wasm parts of the proof can be sped up by 2-3x, based on my experience with hand-optimized Wasm for the Zprize (repo: https://github.com/mitschabaude/montgomery)
We developing zkDatabase as a service 🥰.
Is it a service to execute proof remotely ?
if you want to run proofs server side, you can consider using protokit: https://deploy-preview-1--aesthetic-beijinho-ea3a52.netlify.app/docs/what-is-protokit

messages.content: I can do the same thing with o1js or protokit get extra functionalities ?
you’d have to implement several thousands line of code in o1js to get the same features in o1js directly. Protokit is built with o1js but changes the execution paradigm from off chain to off+on-chain
Yes 🙌

I wonder if there is a Rust equivalent  for Snarky 🤔 
If not, is there anybody who embedded OCaml runtime into a Rust program and successfully used Snarky there?

Plus it seems like Snarky isn't an ultimately large repository.
What does prevent us to have a Rust implementation?
crypto team started a rust impl actually, and use it internally already. search snarky.rs or snarky-rs in the `proof-systems` repo
the bigger issue here is pickles. it's a big and complex library and won't be ported to any other language anytime soon
https://github.com/o1-labs/proof-systems/tree/d37313f7ba80e6d5595458e7580f198dbe39771a/kimchi/src/snarky

messages.content: I know Smart Contracts are basically ZK Programs but is there any OCaml example which can be deployed to Berkeley network?
Or should we implement account updates as public inputs and public outputs as is in OCaml?
Sorry for necro. Why isn't pickles compiled to wasm as well?
And are there any good benchmarks comparing kimchi/pickles proving time vs other langs/backends?
it's OCaml code
it's compiled using js_of_ocaml
It wouldn't necessarily be faster I think because it needs a GC.
It's also somewhat high level already
maybe https://github.com/ocaml-wasm/wasm_of_ocaml _would_ be faster though
I wonder if @gregor has already looked into it

I also think `js_of_ocaml` itself could be made better, there could be more optimizations,
the transformation probably isn't optimal since it goes from bytecode, and I think there is another compiler (Melange?) that does a more high-level translation.
You could probably also get rid of a lot of overhead with a GRIN-like transformation, but that assumes the code is pure, and much of the code isn't.

@gee check this, there's not that much to gain from making pickles' ocaml parts faster.
Heavy parts are in rust/Wasm already! https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1188130683697233973/1194255553959051364
